question: A.04 [1.0 point] A subcritical reactor, keff is increased from 0.876 to 0.914. Which ONE of the following is the amount of reactivity that was added to the core?

answers.feedback: Incorrect. Reference: Burn, Introduction to Nuclear Reactor Operations, Section 3.3.4, page 3-20&21 ∆ρ=(keff2-keff1)/(keff1*keff2) (0.914-0.876)/(0.914*0.876) 0.0475 ∆k/k = 4.75 % ∆k/k
Correct. Reference: Burn, Introduction to Nuclear Reactor Operations, Section 3.3.4, page 3-20&21 ∆ρ=(keff2-keff1)/(keff1*keff2) (0.914-0.876)/(0.914*0.876) 0.0475 ∆k/k = 4.75 % ∆k/k
Incorrect. Reference: Burn, Introduction to Nuclear Reactor Operations, Section 3.3.4, page 3-20&21 ∆ρ=(keff2-keff1)/(keff1*keff2) (0.914-0.876)/(0.914*0.876) 0.0475 ∆k/k = 4.75 % ∆k/k
Incorrect. Reference: Burn, Introduction to Nuclear Reactor Operations, Section 3.3.4, page 3-20&21 ∆ρ=(keff2-keff1)/(keff1*keff2) (0.914-0.876)/(0.914*0.876) 0.0475 ∆k/k = 4.75 % ∆k/k

question: A.08 [1.0 point] Given the thermal neutron flux (Ø) is 1.0 × 1013 neutrons/cm2/second, and the macroscopic cross-section (Σf) for fission is 0.1 cm-1. The fission rate is:

answers.feedback: Incorrect. Reference: Fission rate = thermal flux (Ø) x macroscopic cross-section. (Σf) = (1.0 x 1013 neutrons/cm2/second) x 0.1 cm-1 (Σf) = 1.0 × 1012 neutrons/cm3/second Burn, R., Introduction of Nuclear Reactor Operations, © 1988, Sec 2.6.2

Incorrect. Reference: Fission rate = thermal flux (Ø) x macroscopic cross-section. (Σf) = (1.0 x 1013 neutrons/cm2/second) x 0.1 cm-1 (Σf) = 1.0 × 1012 neutrons/cm3/second Burn, R., Introduction of Nuclear Reactor Operations, © 1988, Sec 2.6.2

Correct. Reference: Fission rate = thermal flux (Ø) x macroscopic cross-section. (Σf) = (1.0 x 1013 neutrons/cm2/second) x 0.1 cm-1 (Σf) = 1.0 × 1012 neutrons/cm3/second Burn, R., Introduction of Nuclear Reactor Operations, © 1988, Sec 2.6.2

Incorrect. Reference: Fission rate = thermal flux (Ø) x macroscopic cross-section. (Σf) = (1.0 x 1013 neutrons/cm2/second) x 0.1 cm-1 (Σf) = 1.0 × 1012 neutrons/cm3/second Burn, R., Introduction of Nuclear Reactor Operations, © 1988, Sec 2.6.2

question: A.09 [1.0 point] Given a reactor period of 17 seconds, how long will it take for reactor power to quadruple?

answers.feedback: Incorrect. Reference: P = P0 et/T  4 = 1t/17s ln(4) = ln(t/17s) 1.386 = t/17s t = (1.386)*17s t = 23.57 seconds
Incorrect. Reference: P = P0 et/T  4 = 1t/17s ln(4) = ln(t/17s) 1.386 = t/17s t = (1.386)*17s t = 23.57 seconds
Correct. Reference: P = P0 et/T  4 = 1t/17s ln(4) = ln(t/17s) 1.386 = t/17s t = (1.386)*17s t = 23.57 seconds
Incorrect. Reference: P = P0 et/T  4 = 1t/17s ln(4) = ln(t/17s) 1.386 = t/17s t = (1.386)*17s t = 23.57 seconds

question: A.12 [1.0 point] Following a reactor scram from 15.6 MW on a light water reactor, the reactor period has stabilized and power level is decreasing at a constant rate. What is the reactor power six minutes following the scram?

answers.feedback: Incorrect. Reference: P = P0 e-t/T P = 15.6 MW * e(360s/-80s) 15.6 MW * e-4.5 15.6 MW * 0.01110899;  P = 0.1733 MW = 173 kW
Incorrect. Reference: P = P0 e-t/T P = 15.6 MW * e(360s/-80s) 15.6 MW * e-4.5 15.6 MW * 0.01110899;  P = 0.1733 MW = 173 kW
Incorrect. Reference: P = P0 e-t/T P = 15.6 MW * e(360s/-80s) 15.6 MW * e-4.5 15.6 MW * 0.01110899;  P = 0.1733 MW = 173 kW

question: A.13 [1.0 point] Which ONE of the following best describes the importance of a negative temperature coefficient of reactivity?

answers.answer: a. An increase in reactor power causes an increase in fuel burnup which results in a positive reactivity addition, causing the power increase to slow or stop.
answers.feedback: Incorrect. Reference: DOE Fundamentals Handbook, Volume 2, Module 3, p. 28

answers.answer: b. An increase in reactor power causes an increase in fuel temperature which results in a positive reactivity addition, causing the power increase to slow or stop.
answers.feedback: Incorrect. Reference: DOE Fundamentals Handbook, Volume 2, Module 3, p. 28

answers.answer: c. An increase in reactor power causes an increase in fuel temperature which results in a negative reactivity addition, causing the power increase to slow or stop.
answers.feedback: Correct. Reference: DOE Fundamentals Handbook, Volume 2, Module 3, p. 28

answers.answer: d. An increase in reactor power causes an increase in fuel burnup which results in a negative reactivity addition, causing the power increase to slow or stop.
answers.feedback: Incorrect. Reference: DOE Fundamentals Handbook, Volume 2, Module 3, p. 28

question: A.14 [1.0 point] Define β:

answers.answer: a. The total fraction of delayed neutrons weighted by the percent of all neutrons contributed by the fuel.
answers.feedback: Incorrect. Reference: DOE Fundamentals Handbook, Nuclear Physics and Reactor Theory, Volume 1, Module 1, page 30

answers.answer: b. The fraction of neutrons at thermal energies which were born as delayed neutrons.
answers.feedback: Incorrect. Reference: DOE Fundamentals Handbook, Nuclear Physics and Reactor Theory, Volume 1, Module 1, page 30

answers.answer: c. The total fraction of all neutrons born as delayed neutrons.
answers.feedback: Correct. Reference: DOE Fundamentals Handbook, Nuclear Physics and Reactor Theory, Volume 1, Module 1, page 30

answers.answer: d. The fraction of neutrons at fast energies which were born as delayed neutrons.
answers.feedback: Incorrect. Reference: DOE Fundamentals Handbook, Nuclear Physics and Reactor Theory, Volume 1, Module 1, page 30

question: A.15 [1.0 point] As new fuel is being loaded into the core, the reactor operator is using a 1/M plot to monitor core loading. Which ONE of the following conditions could result in the reactor reaching criticality mass at a value greater than the predicted critical mass?

answers.answer: a. The detector and source are too close to each other.
answers.feedback: Incorrect. Reference: Burn, Section 5.5, p. 5-18

answers.answer: b. The detector is located so that core load starts at a point close to the detector and subsequent loadings move farther from the detector.
answers.feedback: Incorrect. Reference: Burn, Section 5.5, p. 5-18

answers.answer: c. The detector is located so that core load starts away from the detector and subsequent loading proceeds towards the detector.
answers.feedback: Correct. Reference: Burn, Section 5.5, p. 5-18

answers.answer: d. Too much time elapses between subsequent core loadings.
answers.feedback: Incorrect. Reference: Burn, Section 5.5, p. 5-18

question: A.16 [1.0 point] While bringing the reactor critical, which ONE of the following describes how a subcritical reactor responds to equal insertions of positive reactivity?

answers.answer: a. Each reactivity insertion results in a smaller increase in neutron flux resulting in a shorter time to stabilize.
answers.feedback: Incorrect. Reference: Burn, R., Introduction to Nuclear Reactor Operation, Section 5.3, p. 5-12

answers.answer: b. Each reactivity insertion results in a smaller increase in neutron flux resulting in a longer time to stabilize.
answers.feedback: Incorrect. Reference: Burn, R., Introduction to Nuclear Reactor Operation, Section 5.3, p. 5-12

answers.answer: c. Each reactivity insertion results in a larger increase in neutron flux resulting in a shorter time to stabilize.
answers.feedback: Incorrect. Reference: Burn, R., Introduction to Nuclear Reactor Operation, Section 5.3, p. 5-12

answers.answer: d. Each reactivity insertion results in a larger increase in neutron flux resulting in a longer time to stabilize.
answers.feedback: Correct. Reference: Burn, R., Introduction to Nuclear Reactor Operation, Section 5.3, p. 5-12

question: A.17 [1.0 point] A subcritical reactor has a keff of 0.741. How much reactivity is added to change the keff to 0.966?

answers.feedback: Incorrect. Reference: Burn, Section 3.3.4, p 3-20-21 Δρ = (keff2-keff1)/(keff1*keff2) Δρ = (0.966-0.741) / (0.741*0.966) Δρ = 0.314 Δk/k
Incorrect. Reference: Burn, Section 3.3.4, p 3-20-21 Δρ = (keff2-keff1)/(keff1*keff2) Δρ = (0.966-0.741) / (0.741*0.966) Δρ = 0.314 Δk/k
Correct. Reference: Burn, Section 3.3.4, p 3-20-21 Δρ = (keff2-keff1)/(keff1*keff2) Δρ = (0.966-0.741) / (0.741*0.966) Δρ = 0.314 Δk/k
Incorrect. Reference: Burn, Section 3.3.4, p 3-20-21 Δρ = (keff2-keff1)/(keff1*keff2) Δρ = (0.966-0.741) / (0.741*0.966) Δρ = 0.314 Δk/k

question: A.18 [1.0 point] Which ONE of the following describes Integral Rod Worth?

answers.answer: a. The remaining reactivity worth of a rod up to the point of withdrawal
answers.feedback: Incorrect. Reference: Burn, Introduction to Nuclear Reactor Operations, Section 3.4, page 3-32

answers.answer: b. The plot of the slope of the change in reactivity over the change in rod position (Δρ/Δx)
answers.feedback: Incorrect. Reference: Burn, Introduction to Nuclear Reactor Operations, Section 3.4, page 3-32

answers.answer: c. The reactivity change per unit movement of a rod.
answers.feedback: Incorrect. Reference: Burn, Introduction to Nuclear Reactor Operations, Section 3.4, page 3-32

answers.answer: d. The total reactivity worth of the rod at a particular degree of withdrawal
answers.feedback: Correct. Reference: Burn, Introduction to Nuclear Reactor Operations, Section 3.4, page 3-32

question: A.19 [1.0 point] A reactor contains a neutron source of 1550 neutrons/second. If the stable total neutron production rate is 5100 neutrons/second, what is the value of keff?

answers.feedback: Correct. Reference: Source CR = (S) / (1 – keff) (1550) / (1 - keff) = 5100 keff = 0.696 DOE Fundamentals Handbook Nuclear Physics and Reactor Theory, Volume 2, Module 4, page 4
Incorrect. Reference: Source CR = (S) / (1 – keff) (1550) / (1 - keff) = 5100 keff = 0.696 DOE Fundamentals Handbook Nuclear Physics and Reactor Theory, Volume 2, Module 4, page 4
Incorrect. Reference: Source CR = (S) / (1 – keff) (1550) / (1 - keff) = 5100 keff = 0.696 DOE Fundamentals Handbook Nuclear Physics and Reactor Theory, Volume 2, Module 4, page 4
Incorrect. Reference: Source CR = (S) / (1 – keff) (1550) / (1 - keff) = 5100 keff = 0.696 DOE Fundamentals Handbook Nuclear Physics and Reactor Theory, Volume 2, Module 4, page 4

question: A.20 [1.0 point] The moderator temperature coefficient for a reactor is -0.00071 ∆k/k/oF. What is the total reactivity change caused by a temperature decrease of 75oF?

answers.feedback: Incorrect. Reference: DOE Handbook Nuclear Physics & Reactor Theory, Volume 2, Section “Reactivity”, Subsection “Reactivity Coefficients and Reactivity Defect”, page 21, ∆ρ = αT*∆T = (-0.00071 ∆k/k /oF) * (-75oF) = 0.05325∆k/k

Incorrect. Reference: DOE Handbook Nuclear Physics & Reactor Theory, Volume 2, Section “Reactivity”, Subsection “Reactivity Coefficients and Reactivity Defect”, page 21, ∆ρ = αT*∆T = (-0.00071 ∆k/k /oF) * (-75oF) = 0.05325∆k/k

Incorrect. Reference: DOE Handbook Nuclear Physics & Reactor Theory, Volume 2, Section “Reactivity”, Subsection “Reactivity Coefficients and Reactivity Defect”, page 21, ∆ρ = αT*∆T = (-0.00071 ∆k/k /oF) * (-75oF) = 0.05325∆k/k

Correct. Reference: DOE Handbook Nuclear Physics & Reactor Theory, Volume 2, Section “Reactivity”, Subsection “Reactivity Coefficients and Reactivity Defect”, page 21, ∆ρ = αT*∆T = (-0.00071 ∆k/k /oF) * (-75oF) = 0.05325∆k/k
